A domain-member has a targetRole attribute to locate the domain - member arc network, but the roleRef for the targetRole is commented out in the linkbase containing the targetRole, to force the error message.

Two arcs that represent a consecutive relationship [Def, 2] that exist in different extended-type link elements MUST be connected together using the xbrldt:targetRole attribute. Not doing so causes the construction to be unconnected and results in, for example, empty hypercubes, dimensions and domains. Some tools may raise a warning.

The typedDomainRef attribute correctly appears on a dimension declaration element pointing to a non-abstract item declaration.
Signal xbrldte:TypedDomainRefError because typedDomainRef attribute appears on an XML Schema element definition that is not a dimensional declaration.
Currently allows two dimension declarations which have typedDomainRef attributes whose contents are identical.

Currently allows two dimension declarations which have typedDomainRef attributes that differ  (e.g., one uses "foo.xsd#bar" and the other "../schema/foo.xsd#bar") but locate the same element declaration.
The typedDomainRef attribute correctly locates the declaration of a non-abstract element in the same file.

Check for polymorphism including inherited hypercubes.

For bugzilla #350.  Per e-mail from Maciej on 5 Mar 2009 and bugzilla discussion.  MP writes:  (1) Defaults are global and they do not need consecutive relationships (all, hypercube-dimension) to be applicable to all primary items it a taxonomy (it is my understanding of option 1). (2) Taxonomy has with one item (item, string, non-abstract) and one dimensionItem in the schema. It is linked to the dimension via dimension-default in definition linkbase.  Bugzilla discussion is that this does not create polymorphism for the item that is also the default, because the error only occurs "if there is a cycle in which the primary item source of the hypercube is also a member of the domain of valid members [Def, 12]".
The source of a domain-member relationship is a dimension item declaration, not a primary item.
The source of a domain-member relationship is a hypercube item declaration, not a primary item.
The target of a domain-member relationship is a dimension item declaration, not a primary item.
The target of a domain-member relationship is a hypercube item declaration, not a primary item.
The dimension-default arc role identifies in its source a dimension element and in its target the member who plays the role of the default member.
The source of a dimension-default arc is not a dimension, in this case it is a hypercube.
The target of a dimension-default arc is not a member item, in this case it is a dimension item.
The target of a dimension-default arc is not a member item, in this case it is a dimension item.
Two dimension-default relationships in same role but from different dimensions.
Two dimension-default relationships in same role.
Two dimension-default relationships in different roles.  dimension-default relationships are not scoped, so this is still an error.

There are two dimension-default relationships represented with one arc and two locators sharing the same value in the xlink:label attribute. The two dimension members belongs to the dimension domain so there is an error.
There are two dimension-default arcs in different extended links pointing to the same default member this represents just one relationship. This is not an error.

Two dimension-default relationships with targets in distinct domains.  The spec is currently unclear on whether this is valid http://bugzilla.xbrl.org/show_bug.cgi?id=342, but it should probably be an error.
Not a cycle as only the targetRole should be followed (when present) to build the DRS.
Not a cycle as only the targetRole should be followed (when present) to build the DRS.
domain-member allows undirected cycles.
cycle between 'domain' and 'domainMember'
Like variation 01 but this time there's no doubt its a cycle since it terminates in the same base set as it starts in.
Like variation 01 but without the hypercube.
cycle between 'domain' and 'domainMember'
Like example 04 but with a hypercube.
Similar to example 01 except to find the 'cycle' you have to start from the domain member rather than the domain.
No Hypercube, so no cycles
Signal xbrldte:OutOfDTSSchemaError because typedDomainRef attribute incorrectly locates the declaration of a non-abstract element in a different file that is not part of the taxonomy DTS.
typedDomainRef attribute correctly locates the declaration of a non-abstract element in a different file that is part of the taxonomy DTS.
The instance document instance-A.xbrl refers to the Taxonomy XBRLTaxonomyA.xsd. That taxonomy do not include the schema xNL_Bridge_XBRL.xsd in the DTS so xbrldte:OutOfDTSSchemaError must be raised.

The schema that defines the typed dimension element contains a xs:redefine element. The taxonomy do not contains the redefine-schema.xsd in the DTS. The xbrldt:typedDomainRef points to a new element definition which is valid.

Example 11 of the spec shows how
                        inheritance should work. The validation log should be something like this:
                        PrimaryParent: under the extended link http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/link
                        contains one hypercube with one dimension. That hypercube is invalid. under
                        the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/dim/conf/203/ComplexHypercubeInheritance/role/link2 it
                        contains no hypercubes so no dimensional validation should be performed. The
                        PrimaryParent element is dimensionally invalid. FirstChild (incorrectly
                        called FirstChildren) under the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/link contains two hypercubes: Cube1 contains
                        just one dimension DimensionOne and Cube2 contains just one dimension
                        DimensionTwo. Both hypercubes are invalid so. The element is dimensionally
                        invalid. under the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/dim/conf/203/ComplexHypercubeInheritance/role/link2 it
                        contains no hypercubes so no dimensional validation should be performed. The
                        FirstChild element is dimensionally invalid. SecondChild (incorrectly called
                        SecondChildren) under the extended link http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/link
                        contains two hypercubes: Cube1 contains just one dimension DimensionOne and
                        Cube2 contains just one dimension DimensionTwo. Both hypercubes are invalid
                        so. The element is dimensionally invalid. The SecondChild element is
                        dimensionally invalid. ThirdChild (incorrectly called ThirdChildren) under
                        the extended link http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/link contains two
                        hypercubes: Cube1 contains just one dimension DimensionOne and Cube2
                        contains just one dimension DimensionTwo. Both hypercubes are invalid so.
                        The element is dimensionally invalid. under the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/dim/conf/203/ComplexHypercubeInheritance/role/link2 it
                        contains just one hypercube Cube3 with one dimension DimensionThree. The
                        cube is dimensionally invalid. The ThirdChild element is dimensionally
                        invalid. There are 4 errors represented because none of the primary items to
                        validate are dimensionally valid. IMHO you are considering the elements
                        "PrimaryParent" and "FirstChild" dimensionally valid because they contain no
                        hypercubes in the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/dim/conf/203/ComplexHypercubeInheritance/role/link2 and
                        according to the spec a primary item with no hypercubes is dimensionally
                        valid. The issue here is whether or not "PrimaryParent" and "FirstChild"
                        contains hypercubes in the extended link
                        http://www.xbrl.org/dim/conf/203/ComplexHypercubeInheritance/role/link2. I'm
                        considering that those two elements do not contain hypercubes in the second
                        extended link because the hypercube inheritance goes from top to bottom
                        only. Therefore, ThirdChild do inherit the hypercubes from PrimaryParent
                        because PrimaryParent is the head of the hierarchy.

The effective domain contains
                        the same element twice. That element must be excluded from the domain
                        because it has xbrldt:usable=false in one of the domains.

The effective domain contains
                        the same element twice. That element must be excluded from the domain
                        because it has xbrldt:usable=false in one of the domains.

As per section 3.1 paragraph 4, the
                        primary items in this example are not the source of any dimensional
                        relationship set so they are dimensionally valid

The primary item contains two
                        hypercubes, both have closed=false. The instance document uses the one
                        dimension value element from the 'notAll' hypercube and an additional one to
                        satisfy the 'all' hypercube. Since the 'notAll' hypercube is open it is thus
                        considered hypercube valid, which means that the negated result (as this is
                        a 'notAll' hypercube) is invalid.

The primary item contains two
                        hypercubes, the 'all' cube with closed=false, the 'notAll' with closed=true.
                        The 'all' hypercube is correctly satisfied. The instance document uses the
                        dimension value element prohibited by the 'notAll' hypercube but this
                        hypercube does not include one of the dimensions declared in the 'all'
                        hypercube; because it is considered closed=true the 'notAll' hypercube is
                        thus considered hypercube invalid, which means that the negated result (as
                        this is a 'notAll' hypercube) is valid.

The taxonomy has a primary item A
                        with one closed empty hypercube. There is also a primary item B with a
                        different hypercube with one dimension that has a default member. The item A
                        appears in the instance with nothing in its context. The default member
                        should not be considered when checking that item A satisfies the closedness
                        of its hypercube.

                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link1 is inherited

Bank of Italy contributed
                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link1 scenario is
                        valid because p5 inherits hc1 with dimension dim1-elt1 from its immediate
                        parent p2, but when looking further up the ancestors, hc2 isn't seen because
                        p2 has a targetRole that blocks off p1 (with its hc2) from passing
                        inheritance through p2 to p3 in link 1.

Bank of Italy contributed
                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link1 scenario is
                        invalid because p5 inherits hc1, whose dim1 is missing, from its immediate
                        parent p2, but when looking further up the ancestors, hc2 (whose dim2 is
                        present) isn't seen because p2 has a targetRole that blocks off p1 (with its
                        hc2) from passing inheritance through p2 to p3 in link 1. Thus dim2 is also
                        an extra dimension to the closed hc1. Hc1 has two errors here, missing dim1
                        and extra dim2.

                        is valid for dim1-elt1. Note that although p22 appears twice in link8, where
                        a descendant of p23 (with hc2), that is not seen as the p22 targetRole arc
                        that gives inheritance to p24 is parented by p21.

Bank of Italy contributed
                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link8 scenario is
                        invalid because p24 inherits by p22 targetRole from p21, which has hc1,
                        which is closed and invalid for dim2-elt1. Note that although p22 appears
                        twice in link8, where a descendant of p23 (with hc2), that is not seen as
                        the p22 targetRole arc that gives inheritance to p24 is parented by p21
                        (thus the dim2-elt1 has no way of being valid here).

Bank of Italy contributed
                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link8 scenario is
                        invalid because p24 inherits by p22 targetRole from p23, which has hc2,
                        which is closed and invalid for dim1-elt1. Note that although p22 appears
                        twice in link8, where a descendant of p21 (with hc1), that is not seen as
                        the p22 targetRole arc that gives inheritance to p26 is parented by p23
                        (thus the dim1-elt1 has no way of being valid here).

Bank of Italy contributed
                        inheritance edge use case, tests primary item inheritance and target role
                        navigability in presence of extended link relationships of same nodes as
                        target roles. Contributed by Michele Romanelli. Base set link8 scenario is
                        valid because p24 inherits by p22 targetRole from p23, which has hc2, which
                        is valid for dim2-elt1. Note that although p22 appears twice in link8, where
                        a descendant of p21 (with hc1), that is not seen as the p22 targetRole arc
                        that gives inheritance to p23 is parented by p23.

Test of Spec Example 11, to
                        determine whether hypercubes are being "shared" across
                        base set networks. Valid in Example 11 strict sense because p3 inherits from
                        both base sets link1 and link2, and here in base set link1 there a single
                        hybercube hc1 with dim1_elt1 its only member, which matches context c1. If
                        dimensional processor were to "share" the hypercubes
                        across all, then hc2 might be processed when inheriting from
                        link1.

Test of Spec Example 11, to
                        determine whether hypercubes are being "shared" across
                        base set networks. Valid in Example 11 strict sense because base set link2
                        has a two hybercubes hc1 with dim1_elt2 its only member and hc2 with
                        dim2_elt1, that matches context c1. In a sharing situation a processor may
                        attempt to assure that link1's hc1 entry were valid here too, and fail this
                        case.

Test that closed attribute is
                        inherited by primary item inheritance of hypercubes (not explicity in XDT
                        yet). A processor inheriting hc1 & hc2 in link2closed, and flipping
                        the closed attribute, thinking it open, would not complain that two mutually
                        exclusive hypercubes are invalid here, each with other's dim being
                        extraneous.

Test that closed attribute is
                        inherited by primary item inheritance of hypercubes (not explicity in XDT
                        yet). A processor inheriting hc1 & hc2 in link2open, and flipping
                        the closed attribute, thinking it closed, would complain that each cube then
                        being mutually exclusive, has invalid extra content here.

Test that usable=false attribute
                        is not processed when determining primary item inheritance. This attribute
                        is specified for purposes of exclusion of members from effective domains,
                        and although it may appear on a domain-member arc which somehow gets into a
                        primary item inheritance DRS, such as by targetRole sharing in different
                        base set from where it may participate in specifying hypercube domain
                        members, it isn't to be processed when traversed for purposes of primary
                        item inheritance. In this case the hypercube hc1 would be unseen if some
                        processor utilized the usable=false on primary item inheritance, when
                        evaluating the primary item ancestors in base set for p3 in link1, in which
                        case p1-c1 would be valid, but if hc1 is seen as it should be in the link1
                        base set, dim1_elt1 is unusable and should generate the error.

Test the content of an empty dimension. The instance is valid because
                        the hypercube is invalid and linked with a notAll relationship to the
                        primary item. The dimension content is a QName corresponding to a global
                        element defined in a schema. The schema is in the DTS. The QName is the
                        hypercube definition.

Test the content of an empty dimension. The instance is valid because
                        the hypercube is invalid and linked with a notAll relationship to the
                        primary item. The dimension content is a QName corresponding to a global
                        element defined in a schema. The schema is in the DTS. The QName is the
                        primary item definition.

Point 3.1.3 Fig 4 row 5. It is
                        invalid because the hypercube is closed and contains non expected
                        information

Point 3.1.3 Fig 4 row 6. It is
                        valid because the hypercube is open

From discussion betw. Bernard, Herm and Michele at CEBS Madrid 2009-04.
                   Two dimensions, each with default total member, and child member, in closed hypercube.
                   First dimension also an open notAll hypercube to exclude first dimensions child member.
                   This test case has both dimensions defaulted, dim1 does not match the notAll cube member, 
                   dim2 slips through the notAll's openness, so it is valid.

Same as V-301 but this test case has only dim1 default, dim2 child, the notAll cube
                   doesn't match dim1 and dim2 slips through the notAll's openness, so it is valid.
Same as V-301 but this test case has no default, dim1 child excluded, invalid.

1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value for every dimension. A validator MUST
                        signal [Ins Err, 7] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstance when this rule is
                        violated. In this valid variation only one dimension value is
                        provided.

1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value for every dimension. A validator MUST
                        signal [Ins Err, 7] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstance when this rule is
                        violated. In this case two customer names are provided for the same context
                        segment.

1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value [Def, 15] for each dimension. A
                        validator MUST signal [Ins Err, 3] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstanceError
                        when this rule is violated. In this case an explicit dimension, defined to
                        be locatable in both segment and scenario, appears in only segment, so it is
                        valid.

1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value [Def, 15] for each dimension. A
                        validator MUST signal [Ins Err, 3] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstanceError
                        when this rule is violated. In this case an explicit dimension, defined to
                        be locatable in both segment and scenario, appears twice, once each in both
                        segment and scenario, so by working group voted decision, it is
                        invalid.

1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value [Def, 15] for each dimension. A
                        validator MUST signal [Ins Err, 3] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstanceError
                        when this rule is violated. In this case a typed dimension, defined to be
                        locatable in both segment and scenario, appears in only segment, so it is
                        valid.

1. 1. A context MUST NOT
                        contain more than one dimension value [Def, 15] for each dimension. A
                        validator MUST signal [Ins Err, 3] xbrldie:RepeatedDimensionInInstanceError
                        when this rule is violated. In this case an explicit dimension, defined to
                        be locatable in both segment and scenario, appears twice, once each in both
                        segment and scenario, so by working group voted decision, it is
                        invalid.

This is the same test case
                        as V-04 but the instance contains no facts to validate. is this valid or
                        invalid?
Repeated dimension in scenario

The content of the xlink:href attribute of a xbrldi:typedMember element MUST resolve to an typed dimension within the DTS of the instance document. A dimensional processor MUST raise an error [Ins Err, 8] xbrldie:TypedMemberNotTypedDimension if the content of the xlink:href attribute of xbrldi:explicitMember resolves (with xml:base) to anything other than a typed dimension declaration.  In this case it resolves to an explicit dimension.

The content of the xlink:href attribute of an xbrldi:explicitMember element MUST resolve to an explicit dimension within the DTS of the instance document.  In this case it resolves to a hypercube element instead.  The usual hypercube arc from primary item is not present in this test, to prevent missing dimension errors from also being detected.

The explicit dimension has a qName
			which doesn't correspond to an element declaration in the DTS of the
			instance.

Test the content of an empty dimension. The dimension content is a QName. There
			is no schema defining a global element with the corresponding QName. The QName is
			iso4217:EUR.

Test the content of an empty dimension. The dimension content is a QName. There
			is no schema defining a global element with the corresponding QName. The QName is
			foo:foo.

Test the content of an empty dimension. The dimension content is a QName. There
			*is* a schema defining a global element with the corresponding QName, but the QName is
			not a domain member anywhere.

The typed dimension content [Def, 15] must be
                        an instantiation of the element pointed to by the xbrldt:typedDomainRef of the typed dimension
                        indicated in the dimension attribute of the xbrldi:typedMember element. A dimensional processor
                        MUST raise an error [Ins Err, 7] xbrldie:IllegalTypedDimensionContentError if this rule is
                        violated. In this case the segment contains valid typed dimension content.

Same as above but in this case the scenario
                        contains valid typed dimension content.

Same as above but in this case the segment
                        contains bogus typed dimension content.

Same as above but in this case the scenario
                        contains bogus typed dimension content.

Same as above but in this case the segment
                        contains bogus typed dimension content. No primary item refers to the segment.

Same as above but in this case the scenario
                        contains bogus typed dimension content. No primary item refers to the segment.

Bugzilla 343, e-mail references discussion of default that is illegal, here because for primary item d, closed hypercube 1 does not include the illegal member.  Adapted from V-01-hc1-d1 by adding an illegal default member and only using primary item d.  (Editorial note by Herm: although this situation should be illegal, careful reading of the spec convinces me it is clearly legal in the taxonomy and very fuzzy and multiply-interpretable for the instance, so I did not indicate that any error should be raised.  Whether error or not, the point of the dimensional infoset experience by the item in the processor is the objective.)

Bugzilla 343, dimension default member is not abstract and is used as a fact item, there are no hypercubes.  Base spec meeeting of 2009-06-24 discussed that this is not currently an error (but maybe should have been).  Philosophically it is a kind of primary item to default member polymorphism issue.  However today this variation is valid.
Dump four facts on two axes where there are defaults for both.
Dump four facts on two axes where there are defaults for both.
XBRL 2.1-valid Tuple with contexts having a the segment and scenario.
